item.title: Ralph Northam Resists Calls to Resign as Virginia Governor Over Racist Yearbook Photo
item.media:description: Mr. Northam, a Democrat, was elected in 2017 with a strong vote margin.
item.media:credit: Ting Shen for The New York Times
item.description: Mr. Northam, increasingly isolated over a yearbook photo showing two people in blackface and Ku Klux Klan robes, was calling fellow Democrats to say he did not think it was him in the photo.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN, TRIP GABRIEL and ALAN BLINDER

item.title: White House Memo: What Do You Learn About Trump in an 85-Minute Interview?
item.media:description: President Trump offered plenty of clues for Trumpologists seeking to understand him during an interview with The New York Times on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: Among other things: Who is up and who is down, what he cares about and what he does not, what he knows and what he does not.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MAGGIE HABERMAN

item.title: Trump Sought a Loan During the 2016 Campaign. Deutsche Bank Said No.
item.media:description: Donald J. Trump at the Turnberry resort in June 2016, when he was the presumptive Republican nominee for president. A Trump entity lent at least $45 million to the resort that year.
item.media:credit: Jeff J Mitchell/Getty Images
item.description: Donald Trump turned to the German bank, one of the few lenders willing to do business with him, to borrow millions of dollars that would go to his golf resort in Scotland.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ENRICH, JESSE DRUCKER and BEN PROTESS
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates

item.title: White House Memo: In the Pale of Winter, Trump’s Tan Remains a State Secret
item.media:description: The official line from the White House is that President Trump’s glow is the result of “good genes.”
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: The White House insists that only “good genes” and a clear powder are behind President Trump’s glow, but mysteries about his grooming routine abound.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: Medicare for All Emerges as Early Policy Test for 2020 Democrats
item.media:description: Many Democratic candidates for president, like Senator Elizabeth Warren of Massachusetts, don’t want to wrestle publicly with the details of “Medicare for all,” which would most likely entail raising taxes.
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times
item.description: Many liberals who are influential in the presidential primaries want a single-payer system, but some voters are uneasy about losing private insurance. Most candidates are now walking fine lines.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN MARTIN and ABBY GOODNOUGH

item.title: Japan’s Working Mothers: Record Responsibilities, Little Help from Dads
item.media:description: Kazuko Yoshida doing the family’s laundry after dinner.
item.media:credit: Andrea DiCenzo for The New York Times
item.description: Men in Japan do fewer hours of housework and child care than in any of the world’s richest nations. That keeps women from getting better jobs and holds back the economy.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Our Tokyo Bureau Chief on Where She Finds ‘Bolts of Insight’ (Hint: It’s Outside the Office)
item.description: The Reader Center talks to Motoko Rich about Japanese culture, her stress antidote and children’s novels.
item.dc:creator: LARA TAKENAGA

item.title: For N.F.L. Retirees, Opioids Bring More Pain
item.media:description: Randy Grimes sought help when all the trappings of his N.F.L. life were gone, and now works at a rehabilitation center in Delray Beach, Fla.
item.media:credit: Scott McIntyre for The New York Times
item.description: A brutal game got them hooked on painkillers. In retirement, they battle addiction. The opioid crisis courses through football.
item.dc:creator: KEN BELSON

item.title: Super Bowl LIII: How Did We Get Here? An Illustrated Guide to the N.F.L. Playoffs
item.description: From the Colts toppling the Texans to the pass interference noncall heard ’round the world, the lead-up to this year’s Super Bowl had no shortage of drama.
item.dc:creator: BENJAMIN HOFFMAN and CHRIS MORRIS

item.title: Atlanta Is Throwing Its Own Extended Super Bowl Halftime Show
item.media:description: From left, Lil’ Fate, Lil Jon and Ludacris. Atlanta’s most successful exports helped usher in a weekend of live-music events tied to the Super Bowl.
item.media:credit: Diwang Valdez for The New York Times
item.description: A concert spanning the city’s recent hip-hop history was just a taste of the local flavor on display around the big game this weekend.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI

item.title: 11 of Our Best Weekend Reads
item.media:credit: Paul Bride
item.description: El Chapo’s wife has no regrets. New Overlooked obituaries. Lorena Bobbitt speaks. So does Trump. And more.
item.dc:creator: KALY SOTO

item.title: An Urgent Call for Compromise in Venezuela
item.media:description: The opposition leader Juan Guaidó, president of Venezuela's National Assembly, addressing the news media on Tuesday after a session of the legislative body.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: The risk of a winner-takes-all approach in the country’s political crisis is extraordinary. It’s time to seek a negotiated transition.
item.dc:creator: FRANCISCO RODRÍGUEZ and JEFFREY D. SACHS

item.title: Loose Ends: I Explain All the Sports
item.media:credit: Illustrations by Thoka Maer
item.description: You’ll never have to ask “What’s the Super Bowl?” again.
item.dc:creator: SARAH HUTTO

item.title: One Way to Make College Meaningful
item.media:description: Wait Chapel on the Wake Forest University campus at Winston-Salem, N.C.
item.media:credit: John Greim/LightRocket, via Getty Images
item.description: Don’t find yourself; find a vocation.
item.dc:creator: TOM PERRIN

item.title: Howard Schultz Derangement Syndrome
item.media:description: Howard Schultz at a Starbucks shareholders meeting, in front of a photo of employees.
item.media:credit: Ted S. Warren/Associated Press
item.description: The left’s war on centrism bodes ill for Democratic chances in 2020.
item.dc:creator: BRET STEPHENS

item.title: letter: A Woman’s Plea: Let’s Raise Our Voices!
item.media:credit: Yukai Du
item.description: A reader points out that letters to the editor “skew male.” She’s right. We are determined to publish diverse voices and views, but we need your help.

item.title: How Republicans Erased Trumpism
item.media:description: Mitch McConnell speaking to the media after a luncheon with fellow Republicans on Tuesday.
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.description: G.O.P. congressional leaders used tactics to minimize the president’s influence and maximize their own control over public policy.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW GLASSMAN

item.title: How to Talk Presidential
item.media:credit: Dominick Reuter/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: You can be the political life of the party.
item.dc:creator: GAIL COLLINS

item.title: This General Doesn’t Mention Trump, but His Tweets Speak Volumes
item.media:description: Gen. Martin Dempsey, who retired in 2015, has been tweeting recently about leadership.
item.media:credit: Doug Mills/The New York Times
item.description: A former chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff doles out lessons in restraint for a hot-tempered commander in chief.
item.dc:creator: CAROL GIACOMO
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: The Harm in Hustle Culture
item.media:credit: Joshua Bright for The New York Times
item.description: At the heart of homogenization lies emptiness. Anything-but-this anger follows.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Germany Wants More Women in Politics. But Quotas Are a Bad Idea.
item.description: Forced parity is fundamentally antidemocratic.
item.dc:creator: JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: Welcome to the New Age of Nuclear Instability
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announced today that the United States will withdraw in 180 days from the treaty, which has been a centerpiece of nuclear arms control since the Cold War.
item.media:credit: Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images
item.description: The good news is that the downward spiral can be stopped.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL BRONSON
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: A Hillbilly and a Survivalist Show the Way Out of Trump Country
item.description: One common thread of J.D. Vance’s and Tara Westover’s memoirs is distrust of institutions. Yet it was institutions — the military in one case, college in the other — that saved them.
item.dc:creator: TIMOTHY EGAN
item.category: Hillbilly Elegy: A Memoir of a Family and Culture in Crisis (Book)

item.title: What Science Can Learn From Religion
item.description: Hostility toward spiritual traditions may be hampering empirical inquiry.
item.dc:creator: DAVID DeSTENO

item.title: The Queen of Change
item.media:description: Julia Cameron, making change at 70.
item.media:credit: Ramsay de Give for The New York Times
item.description: With “The Artist’s Way,” Julia Cameron invented the way people renovate the creative soul.
item.dc:creator: PENELOPE GREEN

item.title: Doctors: How One Woman Changed What Doctors Know About Heart Attacks
item.media:description: Katherine Leon, founder of the SCAD Alliance.
item.description: The story of SCAD underscores how much doctors still don’t understand, including about heart disease in women.
item.dc:creator: HAIDER WARRAICH, M.D.

item.title: An Appraisal: Jonas Mekas: A Poet With a Movie Camera
item.media:description: Mekas in 2017. He fought for independent film long before there was a Sundance.
item.media:credit: Edu Bayer for The New York Times
item.description: A filmmaker, cine-evangelist and one of life’s tireless adventurers, the New York auteur sought to free cinema.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS

item.title: Taliban to Meet Afghan Politicians (but Not Ghani) in Moscow
item.media:description: Former President Hamid Karzai will attend upcoming talks in Moscow with the Taliban and other Afghan politicians, his office said.
item.media:credit: Yuri Kochetkov/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.description: President Ashraf Ghani’s Afghan government has been shut out of the insurgents’ peace talks with the United States, and the meeting in Russia could undermine him further.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: A Mayor’s Effort to Play Down Henry Ford’s Anti-Semitism Backfires
item.media:description: Mayor John B. O’Reilly Jr. stopped distribution of a quarterly journal that included a story about Henry Ford’s history of anti-Semitism.
item.media:credit: Danielle Duval/Jackson Citizen Patriot, via Mlive.com, via Associated Press
item.description: The mayor of Dearborn, Mich., halted distribution of a city history magazine documenting Ford’s bigoted views, a move that riled residents and historians.
item.dc:creator: STEVE FRIESS and ADEEL HASSAN

item.title: Justice Alito Temporarily Blocks a Louisiana Abortion Law
item.media:description: Carnations in front of the Supreme Court in January on the 46th anniversary of the Roe v. Wade decision.
item.media:credit: Sarah Silbiger/The New York Times
item.description: The law, requiring abortion providers to have admitting privileges at nearby hospitals, was essentially identical to one in Texas that the justices struck down in 2016.
item.dc:creator: ADAM LIPTAK

item.title: Russia Pulls Out of Nuclear Treaty in ‘Symmetrical’ Response to U.S. Move
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia discussed new weapons systems in a televised meeting on Saturday with Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov, left, and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Nikolsky
item.description: Russia will no longer observe the 1987 nuclear pact, which the Trump administration suspended on Friday. China urged both powers to observe the agreement, but showed no interest in joining it.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament

item.title: Petland Discounts, Whose ’90s Jingle You’re Humming Right Now, May Close
item.media:description: Tatiana Vazquez, the manager of Petland Discounts in Park Slope, offering treats to a dog named Winnie. Ms. Vazquez said on Friday that the store was struggling to compete with online retailers.
item.media:credit: Dave Sanders for The New York Times
item.description: Just days after the death of its owner, the New York-based pet store chain filed notices saying it may have to shutter dozens of stores and lay off workers.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL GOLD and NATE SCHWEBER

item.title: He Committed Murder. Then He Graduated From an Elite Law School. Would You Hire Him as Your Attorney?
item.media:description: Bruce Reilly, deputy director of VOTE, a New Orleans organization that advocates for the formerly incarcerated, was paroled in 2005 after serving time for a 1992 murder.
item.media:credit: William Widmer for The New York Times
item.description: A bipartisan consensus has taken hold: After prison, nonviolent offenders should get a second chance at normal lives. But what about someone whose criminal history — and ambitions — are more extreme?
item.dc:creator: NOAM SCHEIBER

item.title: Venezuelans Opposed to Maduro Pour Into Streets for Day of Protests
item.media:description: Thousands of opposition activists demonstrating in the streets of Caracas, Venezuela, on Saturday.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Leaders hope to capitalize on international pressure against the authoritarian rule of Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: ANA VANESSA HERRERO and NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Ahead of Qatar World Cup, a Gulf Feud Plays Out in the Shadows
item.media:description: Construction continues on Lusail Stadium near Doha, Qatar. The stadium is expected to host the opening and the final of the 2022 World Cup.
item.media:credit: Reuters
item.description: Public relations consultants, Gulf financing and whispered tips: Leaked emails and documents offer a window into a behind-the-scenes campaign to sabotage the 2022 World Cup.
item.dc:creator: JAMES MONTAGUE and TARIQ PANJA

item.title: On Washington: Chamber of Commerce Decides Bipartisanship Is Good Business
item.media:description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce is taking steps intended to help government function better, which would in turn benefit its members.
item.media:credit: Andrew Harrer/Bloomberg
item.description: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce revamps its political scoring system as frustrated business groups try to foster more across-the-aisle solutions.
item.dc:creator: CARL HULSE

item.title: How to Do a Data ‘Cleanse’
item.description: New year, new you, right? You may be headed to the gym, but what about the health of your phone, computer and all your precious data? Here are some tips to get your digital life in order.
item.dc:creator: DAVID POGUE

item.title: How to Make Your Office More Ergonomically Correct
item.media:credit: George Etheredge for The New York Times
item.description: If your office leaves you with pain in your wrists, back or neck, it doesn’t have to be that way — in fact, it shouldn’t. Here’s how to fix it.
item.dc:creator: MELINDA WENNER MOYER

item.title: A Beginner’s Guide to Getting Into Podcasts
item.description: Listen here, friends.
item.dc:creator: RACHEL HOLLIDAY SMITH

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: Billie Eilish’s Pop Nightmare, and 10 More New Songs
item.media:description: Billie Eilish released a new single and announced her debut album, “When We All Fall Asleep, Where Do We Go?”
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images for Kroq, via Entercom
item.description: Hear tracks by YBN Cordae, Lil Peep, Luis Fonsi and others.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: I.V.F. Coverage Is the Benefit Everyone Wants
item.media:description: Fertility drugs and treatments are expensive, but employers have increasingly begun to cover their cost.
item.media:credit: Eric Helgas for The New York Times
item.description: Fertility drugs and treatments are expensive, but employers have increasingly begun to cover their cost.
item.dc:creator: VANESSA GRIGORIADIS

item.title: Eat : How to Make a Store-Bought Camembert Into Something Delightful and Rare
item.media:description: Baked Camembert salad.
item.media:credit: Paola & Murray for The New York Times. Food stylist: Maggie Ruggiero. Prop stylist: Rebecca Bartoshesky.
item.description: How to make a store-bought Camembert into something delightful and rare.
item.dc:creator: TEJAL RAO

item.title: Critic’s Notebook: The Sundance Film Festival Comes Through (Again!)
item.media:description: Jonathan Majors, left, and Jimmie Fails in “The Last Black Man in San Francisco.”
item.media:credit: Peter Prato/A24, via Sundance Institute
item.description: With “The Last Black Man in San Francisco,” “Clemency” and more, this year’s festival had plenty of good and even great movies if not a consensus favorite.
item.dc:creator: MANOHLA DARGIS
item.category: The Last Black Man in San Francisco (Movie)

item.title: A good Appetite: You’ll Want to Put This Chile-Garlic Oil on Everything
item.media:description: A pungent chile oil is well placed as a sauce for chicken cutlets with lemon and capers.
item.media:credit: Andrew Scrivani for The New York Times
item.description: This easy-to-make oil adds spice and crunch to lemony chicken cutlets. Melissa Clark can’t get enough of it.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA CLARK

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and More in February
item.media:description: Clockwise from top left, scenes from “High Flying Bird,” “Won’t You Be My Neighbor?” “Russian Doll” and “Velvet Buzzsaw.”
item.media:credit: Clockwise from top left: Netflix, Focus Features, Netflix, Netflix
item.description: Every month, subscription streaming services add a new batch of titles to their libraries. Here are the ones we think are most interesting for February.
item.dc:creator: JENNIFER VINEYARD

item.title: The New Old Age: When Is the Surgeon Too Old to Operate?
item.media:description: Dr. Herbert Dardik at Englewood Hospital and Medical Center in New Jersey. "The clock ticks," he said, "and I’ve become an advocate for evaluation.”
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.description: A handful of hospitals have instituted mandatory screening procedures for medical professionals over 70. Many have been unenthusiastic about the idea.
item.dc:creator: PAULA SPAN

item.title: Matter: Germs in Your Gut Are Talking to Your Brain. Scientists Want to Know What They’re Saying.
item.media:credit: Sean McSorley
item.description: The body’s microbial community may influence the brain and behavior, perhaps even playing a role in dementia, autism and other disorders.
item.dc:creator: CARL ZIMMER

item.title: Trilobites: You Flushed the Toilet. They Made Some Bricks.
item.media:description: Abbas Mohajerani holds a brick made with biosolid waste, or treated wastewater sludge.
item.media:credit: RMIT University
item.description: Converting biosolids into building materials could keep a lot of leftovers of the waste process out of landfills, and provide other environmental benefits, too.
item.dc:creator: JOANNA KLEIN

item.title: Shortage of Anxiety Drug Leaves Patients Scrambling
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.description: There are no good alternatives to buspirone, so patients who rely on it are struggling.
item.dc:creator: RONI CARYN RABIN
